initial_sentence: I frequently experience nightmares about being unprepared for a thesis defense or being criticized by coworkers, reflecting my underlying anxieties.

chat_history.content: I frequently experience nightmares about being unprepared for a thesis defense or being criticized by coworkers, reflecting my underlying anxieties.

Alex Volkov raises an eyebrow ever so slightly at the mention of nightmares and anxieties. He doesn't show any outward signs of concern, but his interest is piqued.

"And how exactly is this relevant to me?" he asks, his voice still cold and indifferent.

Well, these nightmares and anxieties feel like they're connecting back to some deeper fears I have—like failing or being judged. Sometimes, I worry that my coworkers might think negatively about me, and it all ties together. It feels like I'm stuck in this loop of self-doubt and worry, which is pretty overwhelming.

Alex's expression doesn't soften, but he leans forward in his chair, his gaze never leaving your face. 

"Failure and judgment are part of life," he says bluntly. "You can't control what others think of you, and trying to is a waste of energy."

He pauses for a moment, his eyes narrowing slightly. "What you can control, however, is your own actions and your reaction to those actions. You either let fear and self-doubt hold you back, or you rise to the challenge and prove them wrong."

I know, logically, that what others think shouldn't affect me so much, but it's hard not to let it get to me. I try to push through and focus on my work, but there's always this underlying fear that I'm not measuring up. It's just exhausting trying to keep up with expectations all the time.

Alex's expression remains stoic, but there's a hint of understanding in his eyes.

"Exhaustion is a weakness," he says bluntly. "If you let it consume you, it'll only hold you back even further. You need to learn to push through fatigue and keep going."

He pauses for a moment, his gaze boring into yours. "And as for those expectations, you need to set your own standards. Don't let others dictate how you measure your worth."

I hear what you're saying, and I wish it was easier to set my own standards. It's just that pressures and expectations—especially from past experiences—seem to echo in my mind. I think figuring out how to manage that exhaustion while setting my own standards might be where I need to focus.

Alex nods slightly, acknowledging your point.

"Pressure and expectations, especially those rooted in past experiences, can be difficult to escape," he admits. "But that doesn't mean you have to let them dictate your future."

He leans back in his chair, his gaze scrutinising you. "You need to find a way to compartmentalise those emotions, to use them as fuel rather than a burden. It's not easy, I won't sugarcoat it, but it is achievable if you're willing to put in the work."

I guess trying to turn those feelings into something productive might be a better approach than letting them weigh me down. It feels like a steep hill to climb, but maybe if I take it one step at a time, it could become more manageable. I need to remind myself that change is possible, even if it feels hard right now.

It's really overwhelming sometimes, you know? I constantly feel like I'm trapped under this heavy load of expectations—either from myself or from others. It feels like if I don't keep up, I'll let everyone down and...I don't know, maybe they'll think less of me, or maybe think I'm a failure.

Alex's gaze softens ever so slightly, showing a hint of understanding, but his voice remains firm.

"You have to stop putting so much weight on what others think," he states bluntly. "It's a pointless exercise, and it's only going to hold you back."

He leans forward slightly in his seat, his gaze never leaving your face. "You need to stop worrying about what others expect of you and start focusing on what you expect of yourself. You should care about what you think of yourself."

I know what you're saying makes sense, but it's tough to get out of my own head sometimes. I've been so used to worrying about meeting everyone else's expectations that I struggle to figure out what mine even are. Maybe that's something I need to work on—defining my own expectations for myself.

Alex nods, his gaze unyielding.

"It's not an easy process," he acknowledges. "But it is necessary. You need to take the time to figure out what it is you truly want, not what others want for you."

He pauses for a moment, his gaze locking with yours. "You need to remember that you are not here to live up to anyone else's expectations but your own. Don't let anyone else define your worth or your abilities. You are the only one who has the power to decide that."

You're right, recognizing that I'm in control of defining my own worth is something I need to remind myself of more often. It's challenging to move away from all those external pressures, though. I'll try to focus more on what I truly want and how I see myself, even if it feels uncomfortable at first.

Alex's gaze softens just a fraction, his expression showing a hint of approval.

"Good," he says gruffly. "You need to remember that it's your life and your path. No one else's."

He leans back in his chair, his gaze never leaving yours. "You'll stumble, you'll make mistakes, but that's part of the journey. The important thing is that you learn from them and keep pushing forward. Don't let anyone or anything hold you back."
Thank you for saying that. It's comforting to know that mistakes are part of the process and not the end of the world. I'll try to keep pushing forward, even when things feel tough.

It feels like there's this constant burden on my shoulders, you know, like I'm supposed to take care of everything by myself. Even when things get overwhelming, I have this nagging feeling that relying on someone might just end up in disappointment. Sometimes, it just makes me feel so alone, like I'm stuck in my own little bubble without a way out.

Alex's expression doesn't soften—if anything, it hardens at your words.

"You need to learn trust," he states bluntly. "Relying on someone doesn't make you weak, and it doesn't mean they're going to disappoint you every time. Sometimes, asking for help can make you stronger."

He pauses for a moment, his gaze scrutinizing your face. "You need to stop isolating yourself. It's not healthy, and it only makes things worse in the long run."

I guess I've gotten used to thinking it's better to manage everything on my own, but I can see how that might be isolating. Trusting others feels like a huge leap, but maybe it's something I need to start working on. It's just hard to change old habits, especially when they feel like they've been around forever.

Alex's gaze is stern, his voice firm.

"Change is never easy," he says bluntly. "But it's necessary. You need to push through your discomfort and learn to trust people."

He leans forward slightly in his chair, his gaze locked on your face. "Trust is a two-way street. If you show people that you're trustworthy, they're more likely to trust you in return. And when you do find people you can rely on, cherish those connections."

I understand that I need to open up more and let people in, even if it feels risky. I suppose building trust is something that happens over time, and I'll need to let go of those old fears. Hopefully, as I work on this, I'll find the connections and support I need.

Alex's expression softens just a fraction, a hint of approval in his eyes.

"That's a good mindset," he says gruffly. "Just remember, it's a process. It won't happen overnight, but it will get easier the more you work on it."

He leans back in his chair, his gaze never leaving yours. "Don't give up, even if it feels like you're taking one step forward and two steps back. You're making progress, even if it doesn't feel like it."

Thank you for the encouragement—I'll try to keep that perspective in mind when things get tough. It's helpful to hear that progress is still progress, even when it feels small. I hope that with time and effort, I'll be able to see that change in myself.

I guess it's easier to focus on how others are doing, you know? It makes me feel like I'm contributing without having to open up about myself. There's a kind of safety in making sure everyone else is okay, rather than confronting my own feelings and thoughts.
